EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

?    The facility policy is to adhere, at a minimum, to the applicable Federal and state rules and regulations that govern accidental release prevention and emergency response.

?    The facility handles liquid sulfur dioxide, and anhydrous ammonia. The facility has a process safety program and reviews its processes on a regular basis utilizing the HAZOP (Hazards and Operability Study) method to review any potential hazards.

?    The offsite consequence analysis includes consideration of one ?worst case release? scenario, of sulfur dioxide, and ?alternative release scenario? for sulfur dioxide, and anhydrous ammonia. 

?    A strong emphasis is placed on worker safety and accident prevention.  Conscientious efforts by trained personnel ensure that the facility operates within the guidelines established by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (O

SHA) and its Process Safety Management Program.  Training and experience prepares them to manage operations on a 24-hour a day, 7-day a week schedule.   

?    The facility has not had any reportable accidents from covered processes in the past 5-years.  

?    An emergency response plan for the facility has been prepared and provided to emergency responders, including Monroe County LEPC (local emergency planning committee), local Fire companies, and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources.  The facility was recognized in 1996 by the USEPA (United States Environmental Protection Agency) with the presentation of the ?Partnership Award?.  The award recognizes extraordinary contributions to chemical emergency preparedness and prevention programs.

?    Consideration is underway to change from the bulk storage of sulfur dioxide to significantly smaller cylinder volumes.  If suitable, such a change would remove this chemical from the program as the quantity on site would be less than the threshold planning quantity.
 

?    Worst case accident scenario: The worst-case scenario is the potential failure of a storage tank containing 25,000 pounds of Sulfur Dioxide.  In this scenario, sulfur dioxide would be released onto the ground and evaporating sulfur dioxide could potentially reach offsite endpoints and public receptors.

?    The alternative accident scenarios:  Alternative scenarios for sulfur dioxide and ammonia were selected using the following criteria:
?    Reviewing documented facility incident history;
?    Reviewing documented Process Hazards Analysis;
?    Reviewing published estimated failure rates of equipment; and,
?    Reviewing mitigation devices.

After reviewing the data, it was decided that the facility would use one alternative accident scenario for each covered chemical. Listed below are the two chemicals and their alternative accident scenarios.

Sulfur dioxide alternative accident scenario: This scenario begins with a 1 inch hole in the liquid line (similar to

an open valve) transferring sulfur dioxide from the storage vessel to the mixing tank.  The sulfur dioxide would be released into a containment area that would contain the release.  Evaporating sulfur dioxide could potentially reach offsite endpoints and public receptors.

Ammonia alternative accident Scenario:  This scenario begins with a 1 inch hole in the liquid line (similar to an open valve) transferring ammonia from the storage vessel to the mixing tank.  The ammonia would be released into the atmosphere and evaporating ammonia could potentially reach offsite endpoints and public receptors.

The following administrative controls and mitigation measures are used to protect employees, and limit the distances to the toxic endpoint:
?    Written Operating Procedures, with one and or two operator sign-off for steps.
?    Two Operators perform and monitor critical steps during the manufacture of the products.
?    Extensive Operator training concerning the hazards of the process, and steps needed to correct process deviations.
?    Automatic shutdown system
?    Equipment and process have been designed considering industry standards, and good engineering practices.
?    Procedures developed to maintain the on-going mechanical integrity of the process equipment.
?    Pressure relief/vent headers are closed and vented to a scrubber system designed to mitigate any potential release of hazardous materials.
?    Computer controlled product delivery systems.
?    Containment areas and systems to contain potential releases that might occur.
?    Emergency isolation valves, and emergency shutdown system.
?    Fixed-point monitors used to provide early detection for leaks of hazardous materials.
?    Level indicators, and annunciated alarms on storage tanks, and process vessel to mitigate any overfilling scenarios.
?    System interlocks are provided to prevent multiple failures within the process.
?    Emergency Operations, and Response Procedures for the prompt mitigation of any foreseen problem that could occur.

PREVENTION PROGRAM/PROGRAM LEVEL 3

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION: ? 68.65
The facility maintains a current inventory of process safety information.  Information is in place concerning chemical hazards, chemical processes, and process equipment. Responsibilities have been assigned for gathering this information; the most appropriate and useful location of this information has also been determined. 

PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS ? 68.67
The Maintenance Manager and the Safety Supervisor have received training on PHA methods and safety review.  PHA trained individuals serve as team leaders.  Teams consist of individuals with appropriate expertise and process knowledge.  Ideally, each PHA team will be comprised of the following personnel:
?    Engineering
?    Maintenance
?    Production (Management and hourly)
?    Health and Safety

OPERATING PROCEDURES ? 68.69
Operating procedures include the following information:
?    Steps involved in initial startup, startup after an emergency shutdown or turnaround, normal operations, temporary operations, normal shutdown, and emergency operations and shutdown procedures, including the assignment of responsibility for executing an emergency shutdown;
?    Process conditions and operating steps necessary for safe operation;
?    Consequences and responses to deviations from the process limits for safe operation;
?    Release information, such as the properties and hazards of materials used in the process, precautions to prevent exposure, remedial actions for a release, any special or unique hazards, and quality control of raw materials and hazardous chemical inventories; 
?    Function of safety systems; 
The operating procedures are readily accessible to the operators and are reviewed as often as necessary to ensure that they remain current.  The accuracy of the procedures is certified annually and maintained in the operating manuals located in the production office.
?    Safe work practices include procedures such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry and vess

el opening, and control over entrance and exit of personnel into the facility.

Manufacturing Instructions provide step by step procedures for production of each specific product at the facility and also include selected critical safety and chemical hazard information.  Manufacturing Instructions are developed by an experienced group which includes Technical, QA, Plant Manager, production personnel (operators and supervision as required), Environmental Department, and the Safety Department.  This helps assure that all relevant points of view are considered.  

Current Manufacturing Instructions are modified by QC/QA.  Environmental, Materials Management, Operations, QA/QC, Safety and Technical personnel are responsible for approval.  Changes in the Manufacturing Instructions require using the MOC or Deviation Procedure.  .  

The facility Safety Department is responsible for ensuring that the most current hazard information is available.  The Safety Department also ensures that the information is appropriately disseminated and becomes an integral part of all operator training and SOP development.

General Operating Procedures.   Following is a partial list of SOPs which have been developed to guide the safe operation of our regulated chemicals and highly hazardous chemical processes.  
?    Sulfur Dioxide Unloading
?    Anhydrous Ammonia Unloading
?    Emergency Shut Down of the Reactor
?    Scrubber Operations
?    Process Line Breaking
?    Confined Space Entry
?    Hot Work

OPERATOR TRAINING ? 68.71
    New hires are given a probationary period.  This period involves attending training programs, working in the process area under the guidance of a Supervisor and operator and reviewing varied process and process-related equipment programs (i.e., Manufacturing Instructions).  Certification of competency in doing ones job safely is provided by the Plant Manager for all Supervisors.  Each Supervisor certifies operators that are qualified to operate specific OSHA / EPA covered processes.  Ne

w or transferred employees proceed through an operator-training course as others have previously done.

CONTRACTORS ? 68.87
Management of contractors working in the facility is a significant area of process safety management and risk management program.  The PSM/RMP contractor procedures discussed in this section apply to all contractors who perform maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovations, or specialty work in any area of the facility.  Contractors who provide incidental services which do not influence process safety are not included, such as janitorial work, food and drink services, laundry delivery, or other supply services.  

The comprehensive contractor control program begins with the initial screening of contractors.  Responsibilities are assigned to oversee each aspect of contractor management.  The facility works to minimize the number of contractors entering the facility.  This procedure is an important control; we know our contractors and they are experienced with this facility.

PRE-START UP REVIEW ? 68.77
The facility conducts Pre Startup Safety Reviews on all new or modified processes involving OSHA highly hazardous chemicals, and EPA RMP Chemicals, as well as other significant hazards. 

New products or reactivation of old products can result in new processes being initiated at the facility.  The following types of information can be received from the technology group, other knowledgeable corporate facilities or outside resources:
?    MSDSs;
?    Product Specification Sheets;
?    Research and Development Documents;
?    P&IDs, if produced before; and,
?    Process Technology.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY ? 68.73
An effective preventive maintenance (PM) program is absolutely essential to the safe operation of our processes.  The facility has a detailed and well-organized system of PM, which is summarized below:
?    The PM program is driven by a computerized system called the Maintenance Pac 2 System (MP2), developed by Data Stream.  The system is installed on th

e LAN (local area network), and accessible from a number of computer work stations.  
?    Inspection and testing frequencies are determined through review of manufacturer?s recommendations, industrial good practices, and/or maintenance histories.
?    All process equipment, alarms, safety devices, and response equipment are identified by a unique designation and included on the MP2 system.
?    Maintenance personnel are trained or are experienced in conducting PM and     testing of process equipment.  They receive periodic retraining on general hazards.
?    Any significant deficiencies (i.e., causes a safety or environmental concern or interrupts process operation) are dealt with as a priority and maintenance overtime is automatically approved in the field if necessary.
?    The Maintenance Department conducts routine inspections of equipment.
?    All outside testing contractors are generally experienced with the facility and have received required training on all aspects of the PSM program.

HOT WORK ? 68.85
The facility maintains an effective Hot Work Permit system, as part of an overall permitting system.  It is entitled ?Cutting, Welding, Grinding, and Open Sparks.?  Other permitted activities include Lock Out/Tag Out, and Confined Space Entry.  The Hot Work Permit System and permit form can be found in the Safety Manual.  Management of hot work activity generally relies on the following concepts:
?    NO hot work may be done in this facility without the written permit approval by a knowledgeable management person.  Permits only cover an 8 hour period.
?    All contractors are trained on our Hot Work Permit program.  If this is not followed, they are automatically suspended from the job.
?    All maintenance and operating personnel are trained on the Hot Work procedures.
?    The Hot Work procedure is reviewed annually by the Safety Department, and modifications are made as necessary, based on previous experience.  Obvious required changes would be made as soon as the need arises.

MANAGEMEN

T OF CHANGE ? 68.75
The facility oversees and carefully manages all aspects of process change in process areas and elsewhere throughout the plant.  This level of control is necessary to ensure that no change is allowed to lessen the high degree of process safety currently in place.  Our Management of Change program, which also addresses environmental and quality issues, is found below.  It can be summarized in the following way:
?    Any trained initiator of a potential change makes a knowledgeable decision on whether a process ?change? will occur.
?    The Change is formally documented and responsibilities assigned to ensure that a Safety Review is accomplished, training is done, SOPs are changed, the PM program is updated, and Process Safety Information is expanded.

The plan for managing change works in the following way:
1)    The need for change is recognized by any employee or through a PSARR activity and reported to a trained initiator.
2)    An employee trained on the Management of Change procedure, initiates the Management of Change documentation form.
3)    The initiator of the change fills in the MOC number on all pages of the form, fills out the MOC tracking log sheet, and completes pages one and two of the form, describing the nature, type, and basis of change and assessing the other elements of the PSM, RMP, environmental, and quality programs which will also be affected by the change.  The initiator also checks any additional reviewers required due to the nature of the change.  If the initiator checks yes to PSARR activity in part three, the appropriate form(s) are initiated.  If the initiator does not feel qualified to answer any of the elements in part three, they may be left blank for subsequent reviewers to answer.
4)    On part three, any subsequent reviewer may answer any questions left blank and consider the need for PSARR activity.  On part four, they may request certain other functions to assess the potential safety, environmental, or quality impact of the cha

nge by checking additional boxes.  All designated reviewers must answer the part four question, sign, date, and comment before forwarding to the next reviewer or back to the QA Specialist.  If PSARR activity is considered to be required, the appropriate form(s) are initiated.
5)    When the form returns to the QA specialist, determination of group discussion requirement is made based on comments of others.  The dates for completion of the different elements and assignments of responsibility are made after comments are received and discussed.  The form is then sent to the Plant Manager for approval.
6)    The Plant Manager forwards the form to the initiator to coordinate the completion of all the requirements of part three. 
7)    After a change is approved and accomplished, all elements of PSM, RMP documentation or program elements, as well as environmental or quality program elements, are changed, revised, and resubmitted as required.  All necessary personnel, including outside contractors are made aware of the applicable change before they become involved with the affected operation, or before procedural changes become effective.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE & PLANNING ? 68.95
The facility has addressed emergency response through various regulatory requirements.  The following plans are in place to address emergency planning and response requirements:
?    Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Plan, which was based upon the requirements of the Monroe County Local Emergency Planning Committee;
?    Preparedness, Prevention, and Contingency/Spill Prevention Response (PPC/SPR) Plan; the PPC/SPR plan is required under the Pennsylvania Storage Tank Law because of the use of on site fuel oil; and,
?    The PPC/SPR plan addresses facility response to both on site fuels and highly hazardous chemicals (HHC).  It addresses requirements specified under the following regulations as required under OSHA 1910.119(n):
?    OSHA 1910.120(q)   Emergency Response to Hazardous Substance Releases;
?    OSHA 1910.

165   Employee Alarm Systems; and,
?    1910.38(a)   Emergency Action Plan.

Procedures for handling small releases of HHCs are included in this plan.  The PPC/SPR plan is the primary plan used during emergency situations.  In general, the emergency response plan which covers the entire facility has the following important elements:
?    There is an on site trained Emergency Response Team; all emergency response responsibilities are assigned.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS ? 68.79
The Safety Department is responsible for ensuring that audits are performed as scheduled and findings are documented in a report.  The audit team is responsible for determining corrective measures, which are reviewed and approved by the Management Team.  The Safety Department is responsible for ensuring that the corrective measures are implemented.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION ? 68.81
The facility has an incident investigation program.  The management elements of the program include the following:
?    Incidents are defined as any event that is not considered part of normal operations and involves spills, releases, fires, near miss, and/or explosions and that include reviews of the emergency response actions.  An incident by definition also includes situations where a serious outcome could have occurred but did not occur.
?    Employees are encouraged to notify the Shift Supervisor or the Safety Department of near miss incidents without fear of disciplinary action. 
?    Incident investigations are formally and promptly initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  
?    Each incident is a learning experience which may require changes in facilities, Manufacturing Instructions, process safety information, training, emergency response procedures, maintenance, and other activities identified as a result of the incident investigation.
?    All incident investigation reports require a means of preventing future occurrence and a written follow up implementation plan, as necessary.
?    All incident investigation reports are disseminated

to all employees (i.e., posted on employee bulletin boards), reviewed in Safety Committee meetings, and can be used as examples in safety training classes.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION ? 68.83
The management program for ensuring on going employee participation utilizes a Site Safety Steering Team.  The team may have involvement with the development and maintenance of all process safety management programs, as well as other active teams (i.e., PHA teams).  Process safety information is available to all employees and is located in the PHA manuals for all covered processes.  These manuals are located in the Manufacturing Conference Room.  
 
General Duty Review
Purpose:
This program is designed to address those elements of the Accidental Release provisions of the Clean Air Act, Risk Management Program Provisions, as they apply to General Duty provisions.  These are situations where chemicals are not listed under the EPA?s CAAA Risk Management Program, but may pose some potential risk to the community.

Scope:
After completing a Risk Management Program for those chemicals that are above regulatory threshold planning quantity at the facility, the following chemicals have been identified as those that may pose some potential risk to the community, but are not severe enough to require completion of a Risk Management Plan as outlined in the CAAA:
?    Octene
?    Methanol

Program:
The program is to classify each chemical listed by the EPA Risk Management Program, OSHA Process Safety Management Program, SARA Title III Emergency Plan, or for some other reason.  The general use and handling of each chemical is then explained including applicable containment and release mitigation measures.  Finally the impacts of releases are assessed using EPA approved modeling techniques.

Programs by Chemical:

Octene
Octene is used in the production of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals.  Octene is not listed on the EPA?s RMP program, but it is covered under OSHA?s PSM program as a generic flammable

liquid with the potential of rising above its flash point.  It is received in bulk by tank truck and stored in an above ground diked storage tank.  The tank is inspected daily by Operations as part of the overall bulk chemical storage inspections.  The tank is hard-piped to process vessels to prevent the introduction of oxygen into the system, and to help eliminate and minimize the threat of leak potential.  The facility has determined the following dispersion modeling results.

Octene Scenario #1: Failure of the Octene storage tank into the containment dike.
The octene storage tank catastrophically fails releasing 12,780 gallons of octene into a diked storage area capable of holding the entire amount.  The total mass is assumed to be involved in a vapor cloud fire.  Using EPA formulas, this approach estimates that the resulting vapor cloud fire is 0.34 miles from the point of release.  This distance represents the maximum distance at which the radiant heat effects of vapor cloud fire might have serious consequences.

Octene Scenario #2:  Failure of an unloading hose during the offloading procedure.
This scenario would have less of an impact than scenario #1 has presented.
 
Methanol
Methanol is used in the production of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals.  Methanol is not listed on the EPA?s RMP program, but is covered under OSHA?s PSM program as a generic flammable liquid with the potential of rising above its flash point.  It is received in bulk by tank truck and stored in an above ground diked storage tank.  The tank is inspected daily by Operations as part of the overall bulk chemical storage inspections.  The tank is hard-piped to process vessels to prevent the introduction of oxygen into the system, and to help eliminate, and minimize the threat of leak potential.  The facility maintains a complete PSM program for methanol,  and has determined the following dispersion modeling results.

Methanol Scenario #1: Failure of the methanol storage tank into the cont

ainment dike.
The methanol storage tank catastrophically fails releasing 4,500 gallons of methanol into a diked storage area capable of holding the entire amount.  The total mass is assumed to be involved in a vapor cloud fire.  Using EPA formulas, this approach estimates that the resulting vapor cloud fire is 0.2 miles from the point of release.  This distance represents the maximum distance at which the radiant heat effects of vapor cloud fire might have serious consequences.

Methanol Scenario #2: Failure of an unloading hose during the offloading procedure.
This scenario would have less of an impact than Scenario #1 has presented.
